report_labels.paradox_alert: [Warning] Logic paradox detected. Retesting is recommended.
no_match: Your tendencies are unique and do not align with standard historical models.

questions.text: Q1. In your view, what is the most legitimate source of power for an ideal leader?

options.text: A. Long-standing tradition and the continuity of family bloodlines (including ceremonial and ruling monarchs)
B. Extraordinary courage and an iron fist demonstrated during national turmoil or crisis
C. A professional elite group cultivated and selected through long-term consensus
D. Votes cast by citizens through independent competition within a legal framework

questions.text: Q2. When society faces fundamental disagreements, which decision-making mechanism do you trust most?

options.text: A. Final adjudication on specific issues directly by all citizens
B. Unified instructions from a sole leading body symbolizing national unity
C. Listening to recognized civil representatives while ensuring systemic stability
D. Mediation by traditional families or patriarchal authorities with deep roots

questions.text: Q3. Regarding 'Professionalism' vs. 'Participation' in governance, you lean towards:

options.text: A. Governance should be the responsibility of a professional, disciplined core committee
B. Governance should be open to all political views, ensuring competition even if messy
C. Leaders should seek mandates directly from the people, bypassing bureaucratic intermediaries
D. Elections should serve as a ritual to demonstrate national unity and support for the status quo

questions.text: Q4. If a country needs deep reforms, who is best suited to break the resistance?

options.text: A. A political strongman with absolute prestige, unconstrained by red tape
B. A highly united ruling group that controls core resources
C. A traditional royal family or head of state with natural legitimacy
D. Emerging forces that can freely form parties and win support through debate

questions.text: Q5. How do you view political competition?

options.text: A. Competition should be moderate and never challenge the core leadership
B. Necessary, but major decisions should go to public referendums rather than politicians
C. Competition leads to division; the nation needs unified electoral rituals
D. Winners should be those who prove their control through power competition

questions.text: Q6. Regarding power stability, you believe the most critical factor is:

options.text: A. Establishing clear and unalterable succession bloodlines or sequences
B. Maintaining iteration and self-renewal within the ruling elite
C. Allowing political participation from various sectors within a controlled range
D. Ensuring every citizen has the right to replace the ruler at any time via votes

questions.text: Q7. What kind of government best represents the 'Public Will'?

options.text: A. A strong government that bypasses procedural limits to respond to public sentiment
B. An elite government that rationalizes long-term national interests via strict selection
C. A government with dynamic authorization through widespread competitive elections
D. A government that consults all citizens on every major decision

questions.text: Q8. If elections are held during a transitional period, you believe:

options.text: A. Elections should have no threshold, allowing fair competition for all factions
B. Candidates should be vetted to ensure they do not shock the basic system
C. Elections should serve as a vote of confidence for the current leadership

questions.text: Q9. To ensure high policy continuity (10-20 years), you believe:

options.text: A. A tradition of cross-generation succession or hereditary standards should be set
B. Long-term planning and designation should be handled by the ruling group
C. Law should limit the frequency or topics of competitive elections

questions.text: Q10. Against severe populism, what acts as the best 'firewall'?

options.text: A. Relying on traditional authority with a sense of sacredness
B. Relying on strong individual decisiveness to quickly settle unrest
C. Relying on complex representative and legal procedures to filter impulses

questions.text: Q11. If technology allows 'real-time response,' you believe:

options.text: A. Elections should be replaced by massive real-time public referendums
B. Technology should strengthen leadership mobilization and social consistency
C. Technology should assist the elite in making more precise decisions

questions.text: Q12. Facing an extreme survival crisis like war, power generation should shift to:

options.text: A. De facto personal dominance by a strongman summoned in crisis
B. Collective takeover by a committee of military or security agencies
C. Granting the existing leader the legitimacy for indefinite re-election

questions.text: Q13. If you despise political intrigue among politicians, you prefer:

options.text: A. Letting power pass naturally through family or bloodlines
B. Letting the public vote directly on affairs without intermediate politicians
C. Restricting competition to keep only one efficient governance team

questions.text: Q14. If society demands change but you fear violent conflict, you would choose:

options.text: A. Supporting a capable strongman to take over through informal means
B. Supporting a controlled, step-by-step gradual opening of elections
C. Insisting on a referendum to decide whether to change the status quo

questions.text: Q15. In your opinion, 'The Law' should be:

options.text: A. The supreme principle rulers must obey, even if it reduces efficiency
B. An effective tool for governance, adjustable according to needs
C. A contract resulting from compromise between the ruler and elite factions
D. Subordinate to a higher national will or leader's decision

questions.text: Q16. If a beneficial policy is blocked by a court for being unconstitutional:

options.text: A. Procedures should yield to national interest; bypass the court and enforce it
B. Law is a tool; amend the law to make it legal, then implement it
C. The court ruling must be respected, even if the policy is delayed or fails

questions.text: Q17. Regarding power boundaries in an 'Emergency State', you believe:

options.text: A. The leader's will is supreme command; no civilian rules should apply
B. Leaders can have privileges but must finalize legal procedures afterward
C. Major decisions must pass through set institutions like the Parliament

questions.text: Q18. If law limits the efficiency of fighting crime, you lean towards:

options.text: A. Giving the executive more discretion; law should not be a hurdle
B. Strictly following evidence and procedures, even if criminals escape
C. This trade-off should be determined by all citizens via referendum

questions.text: Q19. Media reports critical of the government should:

options.text: A. Be strictly guided by the state to ensure social consistency
B. Be allowed, but face administrative limits on core decision-making
C. Be independent, acting as an external 'natural enemy' to power

questions.text: Q20. Regarding the status of the Judiciary (Courts), your view is:

options.text: A. It should assist the government in maintaining order and execution
B. It should be neutral but consider political stability in disputes
C. It must be absolute independent, with power to nullify executive acts

questions.text: Q21. When the Parliament and the Executive Head are in a fierce conflict:

options.text: A. The Head's will should prevail to ensure the state isn't paralyzed
B. Resolve it through political bargaining; rules are just a framework
C. It should be settled directly by citizens through a referendum

questions.text: Q22. Personal property and speech rights:

options.text: A. Should serve national goals and can be requisitioned or limited
B. Should be protected by law, but the government can intervene legally
C. Are sacred; no government has the right to infringe on them

questions.text: Q23. Peaceful demonstrations by citizens to express views are:

options.text: A. Disruptions to order; the government should suppress them quickly
B. Allowed within rules, but must not interfere with decision-making
C. Basic rights; the government must respond institutionally

questions.text: Q24. If a policy helps the majority but harms a tiny minority's core rights:

options.text: A. The minority must yield to the majority; the government can act
B. Law must protect the minority unless facing a high judicial challenge
C. Conflict must be solved through wide negotiation and public vote

questions.text: Q25. The difficulty of amending the Constitution or fundamental rules should be:

options.text: A. Very easy, as long as the top leadership deems it necessary
B. Moderate, requiring consultation and bargaining in the Parliament
C. Extremely hard, requiring a full public referendum

questions.text: Q26. When technical bureaucrats execute policies, they should:

options.text: A. Only be responsible to superiors; rules are flexible tools
B. Follow the code, but can adapt under administrative pressure
C. Be strictly limited by audits; power abuse must lead to lawsuits

questions.text: Q27. How do you view direct citizen participation in government decisions?

options.text: A. Decision is the leader's duty; mass participation causes chaos
B. Can consult public opinion on specific issues, but experts decide
C. Law should mandate that major issues be decided by citizens

questions.text: Q28. The core sign of a 'Good Government' is:

options.text: A. Having supreme authority to mobilize resources for great goals
B. Flexibly using legal tools for efficient management and stability
C. Power limited by law and protection of individual liberty

questions.text: Q29. Regarding the Social Contract, you agree more with:

options.text: A. Order over rules; individuals cede autonomy to the state
B. Rules over will; government exists to protect rights
C. Dynamic contract; major decisions updated by voting

questions.text: Q30. If a leader is produced your way, would you grant them extra-legal powers?

options.text: A. Yes, a legitimate leader shouldn't be tied by mediocre rules
B. No, legitimate origin doesn't mean power can be infinite
C. It depends; major authorization should go back to a referendum

questions.text: Q31. When national decision fails, the fundamental remedy is:

options.text: A. Finding and establishing a more insightful heroic leader
B. Strengthening the correction and oversight of collective systems

questions.text: Q32. In selecting high officials, which trait is more legitimate:

options.text: A. Absolute loyalty to the core will and execution capability
B. Balance and compromise reached within the elite group

questions.text: Q33. If a referendum decides to strip minority rights protected by law:

options.text: A. Since it's the public will, law and courts should not intervene
B. Legal procedures are above public will; the decision is null

questions.text: Q34. You prefer to live in:

options.text: A. A system with unfair competition but high efficiency and stability
B. A system with messy competition but transparent rules and rights

questions.text: Q35. Regarding the final decision-making process for major public policies (e.g., taxation, constitutional amendments):

options.text: A. Direct voting by the public on specific proposals, minimizing interference from intermediaries.
B. Deliberation and voting by elected representatives within a representative framework according to legal procedures.
C. Decisions should prioritize equal negotiation and consensus among functional organizations (e.g., government, industry associations, unions) rather than purely by representative bodies.

questions.text: Q36. On 'Hereditary Tradition' vs. 'Modern Administration':

options.text: A. Hereditary tradition should not exist in modern administration
B. Hereditary monarch as a ceremonial symbol; Cabinet makes decisions
C. Traditional authority stays in power; Cabinet and officials obey

questions.text: Q37. If your political enemy takes power fairly and pushes policies you hate:

options.text: A. I lean towards informal means to abolish/limit their power
B. I will wait until next election and use legal checks to block them

questions.text: Q38. Regarding 'Order', your ultimate bottom line is:

options.text: A. Even without law, as long as there's order, society can function
B. Even if temporary chaos, as long as there's law, order will return

questions.text: Q39. The ultimate goal of political power should be:

options.text: A. Achieving a great, collective vision that transcends individuals
B. Providing safe boundaries and rules for personal happiness

questions.text: Q40. If a system brings growth, would you permanently cede participation rights?

options.text: A. Yes, results (growth and stability) are more important than process
B. No, without legitimacy in process, result distribution is unreliable

X1Y1: Personal seizure (X1) × No constraint (Y1). Power concentrated in one, maintained by ideological mobilization and security.
X1Y2: Personal seizure (X1) × Instrumental constraint (Y2). Law as a tool; opposition selectively suppressed.
X2Y2: Elite group selection (X2) × Instrumental constraint (Y2). Collective control by a small circle; procedures serve group interests.
X2Y2_bureaucracy: Single ruling entity governs through a rigorous bureaucratic hierarchy (X2) with administrative control (Y2).
X2Y3: Elite group selection (X2) × Weak constraint (Y3). Consensus reached via bargaining; limited judicial presence.
X2Y4: Elite group selection (X2) × Strong constraint (Y4). Professionally governed and strictly limited by independent judiciary.
X3Y1: Hereditary succession (X3) × No constraint (Y1). Monarch's will is supreme; law and ritual serve the crown.
X3Y4: Hereditary (X3) × Strong constraint (Y4). Ceremonial monarch; gov is elected and constitutionally bound.
X4Y2: Non-competitive (X4) × Instrumental (Y2). Controlled elections provide symbolic procedural legitimacy.
X5Y3: Limited competition (X5) × Weak constraint (Y3). Unequal party play; executive dominates policy.
X6Y4: Full competition (X6) × Strong constraint (Y4). Free elections, independent judiciary, and right protection.
X6Y4_negotiation: Adds social partnership and negotiation mechanisms onto representative democracy (X6/Y4).
X7Y2: Direct mandate (X7) × Instrumental (Y2). Leader bypasses procedures using 'public will' against elites.
X7Y3: Direct mandate (X7) × Weak constraint (Y3). Frequent referendums but easily manipulated/emotional.
X7Y5: Direct mandate (X7) × Double constraint (Y5). Complementary representative and direct participation.

X1Y4: Demanding both a law-breaking strongman (X1) and law-locking stability (Y4) is inconsistent.
X1Y5: Supreme rule of law (Y5) leaves no room for an unconstrained strongman (X1).
X6Y1: Absolute popular will (X6) without constraints (Y1) leads to rapid collapse into purges.
X7Y1: Direct public will (X7) without institutional brakes (Y1) is a shortcut to autocracy.
X4Y4: Total monopoly of power (X4) and independent judiciary (Y4) are mutually exclusive.
X4Y5: Formalized elections (X4) cannot support extreme separation of powers (Y5).
X2Y5: Elite group interests (X2) and universalized rule of law (Y5) have deep structural tension.
